organized from turkey markets rally on a

the day's a comprehensive plan which
includes all the ingredients and 11
people are charged in a billion-dollar
disability fraud related to Long Island
Railroad pensioners this is lame staff
reporting for the New York Times from
Antalya Turkey since June Turkey has
been home to thousands of refugees
fleeing the violence in neighboring
Syria an unknown number of those are
defectors from the Syrian armed forces
in recent months those defectors have
organized into an opposition military
force called the Free Syrian Army
majority of its members are fighting the
government in Syria but does the number
here in Turkey including its commander
Colonel riad el assad I interviewed the
colonel and he says that he is committed
to overthrowing the regime of President
Bashar Assad and seeing a civilian
government take power in Syria Colonel
Assad claims that he has full
operational control of the organizations
more than 10,000 soldiers and 18
battalions Turkey's a pair relationship
with the Free Syrian Army remarks the
dramatic shift its foreign policy
towards Syria just one year ago was a
warm ally the recent months Turkey's
relationship with Syria has collapsed
Turkish officials are angry because
Syria has made repeated promises of
political reform but has so far failed
to see them through markets rally on a
European debt deal and data showing the
u.s. might avoid a double-dip recession
there's jubilation in the markets in
Europe today and a much better tone in
the United States after European leaders
in Brussels this morning reached an
agreement on solving the European debt
crisis after weeks of uncertainty they
may progress on three important fronts a
50-percent haircut for investors who
hold Greek bonds a recapitalisation of
banks in Europe and thirdly a much
enhanced trillion euro bailout fund
which can be used to fight crises should
they spread to other countries like
Italy the haircut on Greek bonds means
that European banks that whole Greek
debt will see their investments cut by a
half to try and help the country state
itself from our side the Greek people
are making a superhuman effort to put
our house in order this is significant
because it looks as though Europe is
addressing its problems if it hadn't
reached a deal it would have been a
disaster festering problems in Europe in
been dragging down the US economy but at
least for now it seems to have turned
the corner gross domestic product
numbers out in the u.s. today show the
economy grew by 2.5% in the third
quarter the strongest performance for a
year and economists are saying this
shows the economy which looked like it
was heading for a double-dip recession
is now strengthening and is pulling away
from that prospect but we shouldn't get
excited too quickly there are still
questions about the US recovery and
about this deal being forged in Europe
it's a short-term fix it means that
banks who will be raising capital may
not be lending at a time when they need
to be to stop the European economy
heading towards recession and in the
longer term it doesn't really address
the bigger question of where his growth
going to come from in Europe and in New
York 11 people are charged in a scheme
where long island railroad workers made
up to a billion dollars in false
disability pension claims what the
doctors the doctors know why they got
x-rays MRIs they have bad backs ab
hearing disabilities and they compel
them and under the law they got an
Occupational disability mr. Rutigliano
made those comments in 2008 in an
interview with New York Times reporters
investigating the disability claims of
long island railroad workers but federal
authorities today charged that some
doctors do lie rutigliano is the former
president of the long island railroad
workers union he was charged along with
two doctors and eight others in a
massive fraud scheme in which hundreds
of workers allegedly made false
disability pension claims under federal
law the railroad workers are entitled to
file for disability claims but in this
instance the doctors the authorities
said prepared fraudulent assessments
that the retirees submitted employees in
many cases after claiming to be too
disabled to
stand sit walk or climb steps retired to
lives of regular golf tennis biking and
aerobics the claims according to federal
authorities could cost the United States
railroad retirement board the agency
that funds the pensions an estimated 1
billion dollars virtually every career
employee of the railroad was applying
for and receiving disability payments
giving the Long Island Railroad a
disability rate of three to four times
that of the average railroad dr. Peter J
Yemen and two other physicians were
responsible for eighty-six percent of
the disability applications filed in
what federal authorities called a
disability mill Rutigliano in his words
crushed his back in an injury at home
since 1988 I worked with a bad back in
the last year before he retired he
worked 500 hours of overtime and did not
take a single sick day he also filed for
and received a disability pension in
2008 he was playing golf regularly
